text: Identification of a human LIM-Hox gene , <extra_id_0> hLH-2 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , aberrantly expressed in chronic myelogenous leukaemia and located on 9q33-34.1 .

We describe the isolation of human <extra_id_0> LH-2 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , a putative transcription factor containing two cysteine-rich regions ( LIM domains ) and a homeobox ( Hox ) DNA - binding domain .
High levels of <extra_id_0> hLH-2 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> expression were observed in all cases of chronic myelogenous leukaemia ( CML ) tested , regardless of disease status .

text: <extra_id_0> hLH-2 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> was mapped to chromosome 9Q33-34.1 , in the same region as the reciprocal translocation that creates the <extra_id_0> BCR <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - <extra_id_0> ABL <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> chimera of the Philadelphia chromosome ( Ph ' ) , the hallmark of CML ; <extra_id_0> hLH-2 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> was retained on the derivative 9 chromosome and is therefore centromeric of <extra_id_0> c-ABL <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> .
The proximity of <extra_id_0> hLH-2 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> to the breakpoint on chromosome 9 raises the possibility of cis-activation by the t ( 9 ; 22 ) ( q34 ; q11 ) translocation .

In addition to finding <extra_id_0> hLH-2 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> expression in all cases of CML , expression was observed in lymphoid malignancies and myeloid cell lines , but not in primary cases of acute myelogenous leukaemia .

text: The role of <extra_id_0> hLH-2 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> in the development or progression of leukaemia is not known .
However , <extra_id_0> hLH-2 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> may prove useful as a marker of CML for monitoring residual disease .
